111.content:
The snow around you stretched on endlessly in all directions, a pale sea of white reflecting the glow of the full moon above. The wind was still, as if the world held its breath. The stars above were like spots of fire, brilliant and beyond counting. The glimmer of the southern lights shifted through the cool colors of blues, purples, and greens, shading the face of the woman before, except she wasn’t really in front of you so much as towering above you.

She was immense, the moon hovering just over her shoulder, casting a shadow upon you. You barely came up to the tops of her bare feet, which oddly enough refused to break through the s now. You looked down and noticed that you too were standing upon the snow. Craning your neck, you gazed pasted the flowing silk dress the figure wore and gazed intently upon her face, her white hair draped around her shoulders. However, she didn’t seem to sense your presence, instead looking somewhere behind you.

“It is done. The one who you sought to erase hath been erased.” The woman’s voice was cold as ice, her eyes changing to match the lights above. Looking behind you, you noticed more giants standing in the snow. They were clothed in furs, standing up to their knees in the snow. All heads were bowed in difference.

“Thank you great spirit.” An old woman spoke, standing at the head of the group. You recognized her as the head priest of the southern water tribe. Her weathered voice shivered with emotion. The spirit continued speaking, ignoring the wise woman’s thanks.

“From this day forth, a name hath been expunged from the world. However, none shall mark its passing. Though the marks of their actions shall yet remain, none shall remember that fateful being whose existence you hath undone. But, though your request I hath granted, be forewarned. Grave repercussions are yet to unfold.” As the white haired spirit finished delivering her words, she vanished. In her place, empty air and smooth snow remained.

The water tribesmen huddled in the dark found themselves suddenly alone, the cold tearing at them despite their furs. Strangely, you realized that you weren’t cold. After a moment more of standing in the cold, the tribesmen all turned, presumably heading for home.

You remained where you were, your mind a haze of broken memories. Where were you? How did you get here? What were you doing in this place? These questions and many more flashed through your mind.

Suddenly, a question came to mind, and panic clutched at your chest. What was your name? No answer was forthcoming, so you set to searching your broken memory for any shred of your past. You found nothing.

Though you could remember how to navigate by the stars and a thousand other useful skills with perfect clarity, when you tried to remember even a minute before you had found yourself staring up at the spirit, your mind went blank. It was if everything before that moment had simply been erased.

Another thought flashed through your mind, and a glimmer of hope flashed through your mind. You knew how to fire bend, though you couldn’t remember ever having been taught. You struck a horse stance, breathing deeply and exhaling slowly. Then, with all the effort available to you, you threw a punch, your red armor jingling as willed a fire ball into existence. Nothing happened.

“I’m afraid that won’t work.” The cold, raspy whisper of the water spirit sounded from behind, startling you. Quickly, you whipped around, only to be confronted by a towering, white figure. She was sitting on the snow, her pale legs crossed and covered by her silken gown. Above, pale pink lips pursed together as if preparing for further speech and pale blue irises the color of ice stared down at you. A thousand threatened to bubble up all at once, but the spirit held up a finger to forestall you.

“I know you have many questions little one, but now is neither the place nor the time. However, do not fear, for I shall explain all things in good time.” As she spoke, she lowered her hand, placing it upon the snow before you. You were only a little more than half the length of her middle finger. You paused a moment to consider before climbing up into her palm.
111.title: Spirits in the South Pole

1111.content:
Sitting upon the cool flesh of the water spirit’s palm, you found yourself oddly comfortable. The air around you should have been freezing, enough to kill a full sized adult in minutes without the proper protection. You weren’t wearing the right protection, and you weren’t full sized. Fire bending could be used to fight off the chill, but you couldn’t fire bend anymore. You wondered why you weren’t already dead. As the water spirit carried you across the flat expanse of the tundra around you, you asked her.

“It is due to my power.” Her voice was still the otherworldly rasp that it had been before, but it had somehow softened. A sad smile graced her pale cheeks as she continued.

“Smaller objects freeze so much faster than larger ones. Had I left you unattended, you would have frozen solid in less than a minute.I'm also the one allowing you to stand upon the snow, rather than letting your armor drag you beneath. Their some of the few mercies I can offer you. ” You considered her words for a moment, before phrasing your next question.

“What happened to me? How did I end up this way?” The spirits face grew sad at your question and long moments dragged by in silence. For a moment, you feared she might refuse to answer you, but eventually her lips parted, remorse threading through her words.

“It’s a curse. One of the most powerful nonlethal curses a spirit can put upon a human. It erases you from the memory of the world, making it as if you had never existed in the eyes of man. Everything you have wrought is left untouched, a letter you may have written, a man you may have killed, but no one remembers who caused such actions. They look upon your signature, but remember not who wrote it.

Not only that, but you are reduced to insignificance. Perhaps it was meant as some form of mercy, to grant you life when death would have meant for a more thorough curse. Perhaps it was some form of torment, to realize that you were nothing and be forced to waste away as such. Who knows? The creator of the curse has long since been missing.”

The words shook you, leaving you feeling empty. Everything you had ever been, everything you had ever done, all of it had been taken from you. What was left? Your next question was bitter upon your tongue.

“Why?”

“Because you were a threat, dead or alive.” Outrage swept through you. How could you be a threat to anyone? But then, knowledge of the war between the fire nation and the rest of the world came to the fore of your mind. You couldn’t remember seeing any part of it yourself, but you knew what horrors had been wrought in the name of conquest. The water spirit continued.

“You were once a fearsome leader amongst the fire nation, loyal and fierce. So, when rumors of a water bender amongst the southern water tribe, so long after the last had been thought to have been killed, you were sent. No one doubted your resolve. If water benders still walked amongst the south, you would find them.

Your orders were to eradicate all water benders in the South Pole, and you followed them religiously, until one day you succeeded. You found the water bender living in plain sight, hidden by their tribesmen. When you tried to apprehend them, the tribesmen rose up to stop you. You decided that the water tribe needed to be taught a lesson for defying the fire nation so earnestly, and that you would return in force. You were on your way back to your ship when you were ambushed.

Your crew, your ship, and all trace of your visit were sunk off shore; however there was still the issue of your disappearance. You were well known as a capable and loyal captain with many friends amongst high ranking officials, and though other captain’s disappearances might be overlooked, yours would not. An investigation would be sent. The tribe’s treachery would be discovered. They needed you not only to disappear, but to have never existed.

It was then that the head priestess sought me out, pleading with me to aid her people. She didn’t need to ask long, for I had watched over the southern water tribe for a great deal of time. I consider them my children.

I told her of the curse, though it pained me to do so. Altering the very nature of the world in such a way, it’s an abomination. However, it was necessary. They brought you to me, and I used my power. You remember the rest.”

Outrage thrummed through your tiny being. War was one thing, but spirit magic was another. In war, you lived and died by your own strength. Your controlled your own fate. However, spirit magic robbed a mortal of such things. Those filthy southern savages had dealt you a fate far worse than death.

Quietly, you fumed, sitting upon the spirit’s hand as she walked across the snow. Where your final destination was and what waited you there were unimportant, only your anger mattered. You didn’t know where the motivation for your anger came from, your memory of such teachings had been erased, but the lessons learned were firmly ingrained in your mind. It was all you had left of your past.

Suddenly, the spirit stopped. Broken from your thoughts, you looked around, seeking some sort of identifying mark. Shocked, you realized that it had become morning already. When had that happened? Ahead, ice met ocean, and you realized that you were upon an ice sheet, floating over the open ocean.

“This is where we part ways.” The spirit was staring at you intently, her icy eyes showing no emotion. You looked around, noticing the complete absence of either shelter or resources. You were doubting your ability to survive in such a place as the spirit laid you upon the ground, your red armor clattering as she sat you upon the snow.
1111.title: Answers

11111.content:
Your head was spinning as you stood upon the snow, the spirit rising once more to her full height after having kneeled to deposit you. The area she had chosen to leave you was little better than a death sentence. There was no shelter, no fresh water, and absolutely no source of food. You shouted up at her, seeking to convince her not to abandon you.

“Wait! If you leave me here, I’ll die.” You voice punched through the utter silence. Icy eyes stared down at you.

“Worry not, for someone shall be by shortly to pick you up, though they know it not. In fact, it is the very person who benefitted most from the erasing of your existence. If any are due the responsibility of your care, it is she.” The spirit paused for a moment to allow you to take in her words before giving a small tut of annoyance.

“However, your attire may complicate matters.” The white haired figure waved her hand.

You quickly looked down at your red and black firebender armor where it clung to your form. Though the cause of your feelings had been forgotten, the familiar feel of steel yet inspired a sense of pride and familiarity deep within your soul. You couldn’t remember anything you had experienced while wearing this armor, but judging by your attachment to it, you probably owned molded steel your life.

Suddenly, the metal around you began to fade, becoming wispy as it peeled away in smoky tendrils. You cried out in anguish, one more piece of your past life being stolen from you before your very eyes. You tried to clutch the tendrils as they snaked away, but you were helpless. It was like trying to catch smoke. Soon enough, you found yourself kneeling in the snow, naked and empty.

“I know this hurts, but it is for the best. Your past life is lost to you now, and a fresh start is required to forge ahead.” Her voice came from above, but your gaze was focused upon the snow between your naked knees.

With the loss of the armor, you had nothing left of you old life. You were a blank slate, empty and devoid of meaning. Why couldn’t you have just been killed? You kneeled naked in the snow for a long time before, with a start, you realized you were starting to feel cold.

You head snapped upwards, seeking where the spirit had only moments ago stood, but finding only air. You were alone, the spirit had abandoned you. You looked down once more and noticed that the snow beneath you was slightly depressed. Even her magic was starting to abandon you.

It didn’t take long for the cold to penetrate your miniscule form. You were only two inches tall, give or take, and two inches of naked flesh did very little to retain body heat. It wasn’t the full cold of the South Pole, else you wouldn’t have lasted ten seconds, but the magic protecting you from its bite was steadily waning. Things were becoming grim.

Whatever the magic which had kept you from breaking through the snow, it was also starting to dissipate. At your light weight, the snow acted more like ice, breaking and fracturing in segments around your feet. You didn’t sink into its white surface, but instead found yourself barefoot upon a sharp surface. It would only be a matter of time before some rogue shard cut you.

As you stood where you had been deposited, the wind began to pick up. It added to your chill, finally causing you to shiver. You felt foolish, standing in the cold to wait on someone you weren’t even sure would come, but you had little other choice. A particularly violent gust came, tossing you face first onto the hard snow.

As you stiffly climbed back to your feet, you realized that you needed shelter. The winds were violent, and by now the chill was starting to dull your senses. If you were going to survive long enough to be discovered, you would need to escape the wind. You began to head off in search of shelter, the ice stinging your bare feet as you walked.
11111.title: Abandoned

111111.content:
As you made your way towards the ocean, you could feel yourself growing colder. The wind was picking up, adding to your distress as you gradually began to grow numb. The soles of your feet were already unfeeling, and without feeling on the bottom of your feet you footing was an unsure thing. You were growing weak, and feared you might be unable to recover from any spill.

Normally, the ocean wouldn’t have been the first location you searched for shelter, the ice surrounding the water tended to be wet and slick, but things were different for someone of your size. Out on the tundra, the wind would have scoured the surface flat for miles around, affording no shelter within walking distance. At the edges of the ice plates, the ice tended to crack and push against itself. Small fragments of ice were often pushed onto larger ones by the press. One such structure could offer you salvation, if you could get there.

There was also the matter of your would be savior. If you were going to be discovered, it was far more likely that you would be discovered near the ocean. People canoed frequently in the South Pole, meaning that every ice edge represented a potential landing zone. The chances of being discovered while wandering within the tundra were slim.

You walked on for a minute or so, gradually growing colder, before the edge of the ice sheet finally resolved itself. Off in the distance, a wavering band of blue wavered over the white horizon. The smell of salt wafted through the air. Irregular shapes could be seen protruding into the field of blue. Even from this distance, jagged mounds of ice could be seen breaking the horizon. Shelter wouldn’t be difficult to find amongst those icy outcroppings, but a long walk yet awaited you. Miserable from the cold, you bowed your head and continued on.

After a further five minutes, you were freezing. All feeling had receded in your arms and legs and your world was little more than cold and the thump of one step after another. You were facing down, watching your feet in cold misery, when the world around you suddenly grew dark. Looking up, a mound of ice several times your own height towered over you.

The ice before you obscured the sunlight, along with what little warmth it offered. An aura of cold was radiating from the large hunk of ice, and its surface gleamed, but as you risked a touch, you discovered the mass was dry. The waters must have been calm recently.

The wind suddenly picked up, and a wracking cough was forced from you. You bent double, needles pricking your lungs as you wheezed and sputtered. When you were finally finished, a fire had set in your lungs, alerting you to the stress that such violent outbursts would warrant. You needed to get out of the wind at the very least, or else even if you were discovered, you would simply die of a cough anyways.
111111.title: Moving Forward

1111111.content:
Miserable, you shuffled around the side of the ice mound, seeking some sort of cove to shelter from the wind. Your feet no longer ached whenever you stepped upon them, but that didn’t seem like a good thing at the moment. Looking down, you saw that they were coated in snow, the sharp crystals sticking to your nearly frozen flesh. If you didn’t warm them up soon, you would probably lose a foot.

You rounded the ice and the warming sun once more shone upon you. For a moment, you even felt warm. However, you knew it was only a relative warmth. With every moment which passed, you could feel the magic which kept you from freezing slowly weakening. You realized that you would die of cold long before the magic completely faded.

Perhaps it was for the best? You couldn’t remember your past, nor could you remember your motivations, but instinctively you knew that the past you would have rather died than become some insignificant spec. However, the new you wasn’t so prideful. Despite the horror which filled you at the thought of a life dependant on others for survival, your will to survive was strong.

As you reached the half way mark upon your trek around the ice mound, a sudden shape appeared. It was some sort of brown leather pouch, its top sealed tight with a sinew cord. It was set off some distance from the ice mound, meaning that if you did use it for shelter the ice wouldn’t immediately rob you of any accumulated heat. With sudden elation, you realized that you might actually survive long enough to be rescued.

With newfound enthusiasm, you bounded across the snow, eager to reach the newfound insulation. Your bare feet smacked loudly as they broke through the hard frozen snow and the wind whistled against your bare flesh, but it didn’t matter.

As you finally reached the leather pouch, you were in for another pleasant surprise. It was warm. You couldn’t remember anything ever having felt so good, and then laughed at the thought. You couldn’t remember anything beyond an hour ago. A new thought entered your head and your laughter grew in intensity. The bag was warm. Someone had been holding it not long ago. You were saved.

With half frozen limbs, you climbed onto the sack, knocking it onto its side despite being nearly twice your height. You shuffled onto the warm leather, eager to tear at the draw strings, to climb into its warm embrace. The heat soaked into you, despite the brief time which you had spent upon the leather surface. The soft jangle of equipment could be heard as you shuffled your way towards the knot at the top of the bag.
1111111.title: Hopeful Signs

11111111.content:
As you reached the top of the bag and took a look at the knot, doubt began to gnaw at you. It was neat knot, coiling around the opening to seal it tight. You feared that the knot was far too tight for your nearly frozen hands to open, and soon enough your fears were gratified. You grasped the nearest coil and tugged at it, and a feeling of dread filled you as the knot refused to budge.

Over the next minute, you tried to work your fingers in between the strips of sinew in order to pry the knot loose. Your efforts returned feeling to your hands, filling them with a throbbing, prickly pain. At one point, you even tried to bite through the bindings, but your efforts only left you with a sore jaw.

Though the fading magic of the spirit protected you from the full bite of the southern cold, the bag enjoyed no such protection. The heat of the bag had faded after a dozen or so seconds, even as you had continued to work at the knot. Even now, the leather was stiffening beneath you. You couldn’t have missed the bags owner by more than a minute, judging by how quickly the leather was losing its heat. Unfortunately you weren’t sure whether or not you would survive long enough to be found.

Your progress slowed once more as the protective magic continued to fade. The momentary heat of the bag had only served to remind you of how cold you were, leaving you even more miserable than before. You could feel your hands growing numb, and with dread you realized that you didn’t have the strength to undo the knot. You were stuck outside.

Defeated, you curled into a ball upon the cold surface of the leather beneath you. However, instead of gathering heat and insulating you as you had hoped, the leather remained cold. It was then that you realized your mistake. At your size, the surrounding cold was more than enough to overwhelm what little heat you could form, despite the insulation. The bag wouldn’t save you.

However, there was one bit of good that came from all of your efforts. Between the ice chunk and the depression in the bag within which you lay, the wind was mostly obscured. Not only that, but the leather beneath you was soft. Well, soft was a relative term when most feeling had left your body and a load of unknown tools lay hidden within the bag, but it was better than lying on the hard, frozen snow. Too tired to contemplate the thought of rising, you remained where you were, hoping to be discovered.
11111111.title: A Bit of a Bind

111111111.content:
The world around you was beginning to fade as you lay upon the cold leather of the pouch. Your hands, your feet, your face, everything was lost to you within the void of numbness. Your eyelids felt heavy, and a deep drowsiness threatened to claim you. Above, the wind swirled past, setting snowflakes to dance.

Was this how it would end? Were you to simply die in the cold, not a soul to morn for the lonely, forgotten commander? A deep sadness began to claim you at such morbid thoughts.

Death was supposed to be the ending; the final chapter in the story of someone’s life. However, what awaited you wasn’t a conclusion, but non existence. All of your triumphs, all of your failures, the things you’d loved and lost, all of it was gone. Your story was one that would never be written, never remembered. You yourself would be incapable of bringing your life’s tale with you to the afterlife. The thought was saddening. What were you without your memories?

Nothing. What was a man without his father’s teachings? What was a woman without her mother’s love? Everything which had shaped you, built you, and molded you throughout your life had simply ceased to exist. You were a blank slate.

Was that really such a bad thing, all things considered? You were about to die after all. If you had been washed clean of everything which had made you great, you had also been washed clean of all your misdeeds. You couldn’t remember what kind of person you had been, but a fresh start might have been nice.

Ah, but that was just wishful thinking. Even now, you could feel your eyelids slipping slowly downward. Each blink brought your eyes closer closing forever. Any previous anger or outrage at your predicament was cooling, even as your body continued to cool. What you felt now was tired disappointment at the last flickering of your life.

All of a sudden, you found yourself staring up at the sky. Something had stirred you from your thoughts, halting your descent towards eternal sleep. Your eyelids hung heavily as you struggled to turn your head, seeking out what disturbance had caught your attention. It was only by the barest of margins that you managed to turn your head, catching sight of the beautiful young girl walking along the shore. She looked like an angel.

The sun seemed to shine down upon her, making the white ring of fur around her blue leather hood seem a blazing halo. The rest of her coat and pants were blue as well, trimmed with white fur and complimented by leather boots, but this wasn’t what caught your attention. No, it was her eyes.

Bright, blue disks the color of the sky glistened against a backdrop of pale, brown skin. A gentle nose sloped delicately above a half cocked smile. Her bangs were bound in twin braids which arced outward to fall behind her ears. A flash of light gleamed from somewhere beneath her chin, and you took note of the choker bound tightly around her slender neck, an amulet of some sort affixed at the nape. A light humming filled the air. The rest of her head was obscured beneath her hood, but somehow the girl seemed to exude an aura of gentleness.

The last sight you saw was that of the young girl's cheerful smile before you slipped into oblivion.

As Katara walked towards the shore off in the distance, she couldn’t help but hum. Today was a beautiful day. The sun was shining, the skies were clear, and only a light breeze blew. Best of all, Katara had caught up with all of her chores, leaving her an entire day to do as she pleased.

Of course, she had chosen to practice her water bending, unskilled though it was. She was a waterbender, the last in the southern pole, which meant that she had no one else to teach her. She often felt alone, amongst people who couldn’t understand what it was to be a bender, but that didn’t matter when she was training alone.

It had been a relatively short walk from the village to the icy plot where she had finally chosen to practice. It was close enough that she wouldn’t require the use of a canoe, yet far enough that she wouldn’t disturb others. The snow was packed flat and hard in that area, allowing for relatively steady footing. Not only that, but the ice deposits from the spring crush had formed an ace barrier, giving succor from the wind which blew off of the ice plains.

Truth be told, Katara had really felt she needed this free time. Something had been bothering her since the other day, though she didn’t know what, leaving her feeling angry and fearful, but for the life of her she couldn’t remember what it had been. Eventually, she had chalked it up to mere restlessness. After a good night’s sleep and waking to the prospect of a free day, Katara had nearly forgotten her earlier discomfort, almost as if by magic.

Of course, spending the day away the village had left her without a few niceties. First of all, Katara had packed a breakfast of salted jerky in her pack, preferring not to waste the precious little free time she had. She had chewed the jerky on her way, and had even done an hour’s practice before the salt had kicked in, filling her bladder to bursting. Denied the use of the village’s facilities and fearful of passersby, Katara had been forced to relieve herself further away from the shore. Thus, did Katara find herself walking home, having relieved herself in the relative privacy of the abandoned plains.

The day was yet young as Katara met the shore, turning to follow it back from her morning release. Her leather clothes and boots were snug and warm, rendering the chill of the southern pole mute. She felt so alive this morning, as if a great burden had been lifted as she slept. After a minute or so of walking, she spotted the place she’d chosen to practice, her throat still buzzing with a happy tune.
111111111.title: Katara

choices: Katara Tries to Warm You in Her Hands
1111111111.content:
As Katara walked into the clearing where she had been training, she was already contemplating what she would practice next. She had a moderate talent for manipulating water, though she would need a lot more practice before it became useful, but she had yet to learn the basics of bending snow or ice. Perhaps she should spend the next hour or so trying to.

However, as the fledgling bender got close enough to see her pouch clearly, the smile slipped from her face. Her pouch was on its side, unlike how she had left it. Something or someone had tampered with her belongings. A surge of worry shot through Katara as she rushed towards her bag.

The bag’s contents weren’t irreplaceable, unlike her mother’s necklace, but they were important none the less; a fire starting kit, an emergency line and hook, and everything else she needed should trouble arise out on the open ice. They were important objects which any southern tribesmen would be loath to go without, even this close to their village. If something had happened to her stuff…

However, as she drew nearer, it became apparent that the sack’s bindings remained drawn tight. What’s more, something had been placed upon the indented leather. About a dozen feet from her bag, she slowed to a walk, more curious now than alarmed. Well, this was odd. Upon reaching her toppled bag, Katara dropped to one knee.

Strangely enough, what appeared to be a small doll rested upon her pack. It was a mere two inches long and was surprisingly stark naked. Looking closer, Katara realized that an insane amount of detail had been put into this doll as it was anatomically correct. Perhaps one of the local village children was playing some prank on her? However, the children wouldn’t be allowed to wonder so far without adult supervision. What was going on?

Gently, the Katara brought her gloved hand downward, seeking to pick the doll up for a closer inspection. However, the young waterbender’s heart almost stopped when, just as she was about to pick up the strange object, it twitched. Katara fell over backwards in her surprise, tripping over her feet to fall flat on her butt in the snow.

Warily, Katara collected herself and crept slowly towards her bag once more. What in the world was happening? It couldn’t actually be a person could it? However, as Katara crept closer, the prone form remained still, leaving her unsure.

At first, Katara was wary. What if this were some spirit come to play tricks on her like in the children’s stories? What if this was some other worldly creature come to take advantage? However, after a dozen or so seconds with no further movement from the strange figure, she decided against it. If it were really some spirit come to trick her into disaster, it would have done something by now, rather than just laying there. It had to be one of the village children playing a prank on her.

However, despite the girl's surety that no actual magic was at play, she still feared to approach the doll. There was still something off, something she couldn't explain. She had been sure that the figure had moved of its own accord. After long moments of waiting, Katara’s curiosity got the better of her. The cool air stung her hand as she slipped if from her cozy glove, and she gently pressed her bare hand forward to touch the figure upon her pouch. A touch of warmth licked her hand.

A moment of shock struck the young water tribeswoman before she finally collected herself. How could this be? Upon closer inspection, she realized the body before her wasn’t nearly as warm as she had first thought. In fact, it was only a little warmer than the surrounding leather, which was itself little only a warmer than the snow. If this was in fact a living person, they weren’t far off from freezing to death.
1111111111.title: Found

choices: Katara Warms You in Between Her Breasts
11111111111.content:
Katara had a moment of astonishment as the magnitude of her situation hit her. The figure before her wasn’t a doll, but a living breathing whatever it was. She still couldn’t bring herself to believe that a human could end up that small, no matter what magic was at play, but the heat alone was enough to prove it alive.

Another thought suddenly came unbidden into Katara’s head. They were freezing to death! Sure, it wasn’t nearly as fast as expected, but even in the few seconds that she had held her fingers against the prone form, she had noticed a drop in temperature. Another person’s fate, human or not, rested solely in her hands. If left to their own devices, they would surely freeze and die. The responsibility which the fourteen year old girl now found resting upon her shoulders nearly paralyzed her with fear.

Katara was a gentle soul. She had great empathy for others, seeking to spare them hurt whenever possible. The thought that someone might live or die because of her actions, that she could potentially be responsible for their tragic end filled her with terror.

However, Katara didn’t have time to worry. Instead, she jumped to action; biting her other glove to pull it off before gently scooping the miniature person up off of the pouch. She cupped her hands around the cooling form, heedless that she was now caressing the bare flesh of another person, in an attempt to warm them up.

However, after a few minutes with her hands exposed, Katara realized her efforts were in vain. Instead of warming her charge, her hands began to cool. She tried breathing into her cupped palms, but it only slowed the heat loss. The warmth of her hands wasn’t nearly enough to stave off the chill of the south, even on such a relatively warm day as this.

Gradually, it dawned upon Katara; she needed to try something else. The unconscious person currently cupped in her hands needed a greater hear source if they were going to survive. They needed a fire, dry blankets, and everything else which she didn’t have. However, there was one place Katara could keep them. It was certainly warm, though the thought of placing a miniature person there made Katara blush.

Katara shook her head, dispelling the embarrassed hesitance which had been about to wash over her. This was another’s life she was talking about. There was no room for modesty.
11111111111.title: Realizations

111111111111.content:
Hesitantly, Katara brought one of her hands up to the neck of her coat, hooking her finger and pulling it outward. Carefully, she held the tiny figure in her other hand, pressing it against her stomach in an attempt to keep them warm. However, she couldn’t bring herself to move. Never in her life would the young bender have even considered what she was about to do unless another’s life had depended on it.

However, this tiny person’s life did depend on Katara finding him warmth. You hadn’t always been so small. Not even three months ago you would have been able to look people in the eye without craning your neck. Your life had been a simple and happy one. That had all been taken from you.

11211112111121.content:
With relief so near at hand, Toph’s need suddenly and painfully spiked. All else, including her tiny passenger, were forgotten as she barged through the door, her maid waiting discretely on the other side of the door. Before the small girl even reached the chamber pot, she had already hiked her nightgown high. Without anything resembling the grace of a noble born lady, Toph planted her butt upon the cold, wooden seat which supported her above the pot. Absentmindedly, she noted that the pot had been cleaned before nightfall.

~~~~~~~~~~

As Toph barged through the door, the movement’s which jostled you became much more violent. You were disoriented, tossing and turning within the blind girl’s damp pits, leaving you unable to tell up from down. A quick turn suddenly whipped you against one side of her pit, though only for a moment.

How long would this confinement last? How much would you have to endure? The thoughts raced through your mind as the pit dropped out of your stomach. Was she sitting?

The question was quickly answered as the pressure holding Toph’s arm pressed against her side momentarily relaxed. The flesh beneath you parted, and feet shot through the gap. Your body followed a moment later as you plummeted towards a hard, iron landing. However, you were not to die this day.

Although the initial fall had taken you by surprise, you recovered almost immediately. You clutched at the cloth of Toph’s nightgown as it raced by, hoping to stop your downward decent. However, the slickness of sweat and slime upon your hands weakened your grip. You caught a hold of the silky fabric twice and lost it twice before you felt yourself finally grip the fabric tightly enough to bring your decent to a stop, the remainder of the cloth only just brushing your chest before it ended.

Despite the luck which saved your life, it was your own body which failed you. Your hand had been jerked severely by the sudden stop, sending a jolt of pain through your body. It had robbed you of the precious moment which would have allowed you to grasp with your other hand, damning you.

As the breath surged out of you, you felt your grip release. Terror gripped you as you flung your other arm upward, just missing the edge. Your back met the side of the pot, turning you as you slid down the iron slope. Your slide turned to a roll at the bottom, spinning and disorienting you. When you finally regained your senses, you found yourself lying face up on the bottom of the chamber pot. Though no light touched you, as it was night and Toph had no need of a candle, you could see nothing. Still, you imagined that you could just make out the curves of Toph’s thighs and butt overhead, a valley of darkness held between them.
11211112111121.title: You Fall Out of Toph's Armpit

112111121111212.content:
Toph was only just relaxing when she remembered the tiny person under her arm. A blush shot through her face at the thought of having her friend, a person she had first met less than six hours prior, stuck in the bathroom with her as she did her business. It was mortifying. Thankfully, his struggles within her pit had stopped, but she knew they were there. She should probably take him out and give him a bit of fresh air, but she didn’t want him looking at her as she relieved herself; it would make it impossible to relax. She decided that she would just have to wait until after she was done to check up on him.

~~~~~~~~~~

Meanwhile, within the black pot, your head was spinning. Between the initial impact with the side of the pot and the spinning involved in rolling down the side, it was hard to tell left from right. Surprisingly, you hadn’t made a sound during your fall, due either to the thick iron absorbing the blow or the air rushing from your lungs in surprise as you first began to fall. Regardless, you had to stand up and tell Toph where you were.

You flopped onto your stomach, pressing your hands firmly against the ground as you slowly hoisted yourself up. Shaky legs supported your wobbling mass as you managed to stand upright. The effort left you nauseous, leaving you bent over and heaving. It was in this position that the first splashes hit you.

The warm liquid didn’t hit you directly. Instead, it curved towards what you assumed was the front of the pot. The musky reek of ammonia struck you, raising your nausea to new heights and causing you to retch. Tiny droplets splattered away to land upon you, soaking the rags which you counted as clothing.

“This isn’t happening, this can’t be happening,” you thought to yourself in horror. You needed to grasp your breath and shout an alarm, anything to stop the foamy torrent which now lapped at your ankles.

It only took another few seconds for you to gather enough breath to shout, by which time the urine was lapping at your knees. The slight current from the still falling torrent threatened to topple you while the penetrating warmth left you feeling vile and sick. However, when you opened your mouth to shout for help, a deafening roar called out from above; a wet, sputtering accompanied by a foul breeze.

You had thought that your nose had stopped working before, but you had been wrong.

~~~~~~~~~~

Toph blushed as she broke wind, praying that the tiny man within her armpit couldn’t hear the trickle of her pee or the sputtering of her farts. It was a futile prayer she knew, and for that her face was rosy pink. Her embarrassment was greater than anything she had ever felt before. If it had been someone she didn’t care about, she probably wouldn’t have given a thought to subjecting them to the darker functions of her body, so long as her parents never found out of course. However, this was someone she had befriended and who had befriended her. It was different somehow. That difference only deepened the red of her cheeks.

A burbling groan rumbled though the small, blind girl’s gut, signaling the approach of the slimy behemoth which had been growing deep inside her over the past hours. Its approach sent cold shivers down the young noble’s spine. She wasn’t looking forward to this, but it was necessary. All she could hope for is that it would end soon so she could rush back to her room and pretend she hadn’t just taken a crap with her newest friend riding shotgun.

~~~~~~~~~~

The blast of wind had caught you at a bad time. You had just shouted, though you doubted it had been heard, and went to take another breath when the foul stink reached you. It was a damp stench, groping deeply into your mouth and lungs while clutching at you. You could taste and smell it as it surged to fill you. It clung to you like a damp cloth, coating you in a cloak from which there was no escape.

You collapsed, falling sideways into the noxious urine. Thankfully, the stream had stopped and the current had lessened, but still it rose to about mid thigh. For a moment, you head plunged beneath its musky surface, replacing the foul stench for one far more acrid. You surfaced reeking, coughing, and sputtering and had only just regained your footing when the first one came.

The beast dropped down from the darkness above, its long, blunted head charging downward. In the darkness, you sensed an uneven roundness to it, giving it a bulbous sense to it. Had the scent of urine not been so choking, you doubtlessly would have been first alerted by its pungent, fecal odor. As things stood, it dropped down unannounced, catching you nearly by surprise as it splashed down directly next to your tiny form. The resulting splash flung you to the far side of the pot, far from danger yet still reeling.

~~~~~~~~~~

After pinching off the first of her pungent embarrassments, Toph found it easier to push out more. The damage had already been done. She had released her foul cargo in the presence of her newest acquaintance. Now, she just wanted to get it over with as soon as possible.

Two more slimy snakes slither out from deep within the young bender’s bowels to lazily coil beneath her. However, despite her embarrassment, she truly felt relieved. She had been stressed of late and hadn’t been able to relieve herself for a few days. It was only ill fortune that she had to drag her friend along to witness her relief. However, it wasn’t like they wouldn’t forgive her. Everyone experiences a little incontinence every once in a while. The words buoyed Toph as she cleansed herself and stood to leave. The thought of raising her armpit to allow her silent witness a better look at her handiwork still seemed unappealing however, so Toph decided to leave them where they were for the moment.

~~~~~~~~~~

The horror of your situation could only be hinted at through thought or word. Though you hadn’t been near the center of the chamber pot, the horrid cargo which had been dropped had splashed you so violently with urine that you had nearly drowned. The stench which you had only grasped at earlier was now a choking monstrosity which fought to smother you. Little bits of solid waste had bombarded you, sticking to you and weighing you down towards a yellow death. Flavors and smells penetrated you, inescapable in their intensity.

The heat which permeated your small form was perhaps the worst of it all. Your current, lesser mass left you vulnerable to temperature changes, amplifying the impact of the residual body heat. Where otherwise heat would have been welcome to your temperature sensitive body, it now acted instead to sap your strength. You needed to get her attention, but you would be better heard from the center of the pot. However, there was always the chance that a log might come crashing down, crushing you into the iron floor, but you had to try. You felt yourself staggering as you slogged your way towards the center.

“Toph!” you yelled, your voice a hoarse croak as you called to your savior. You doubted she heard your puny voice, you yourself could scarcely hear it after all, buy you had to keep trying.

“Toph! Help me. Please.” You voice seemed to gain strength the more you yelled. Why she hadn’t noticed your absence so far was beyond you, but it didn’t matter. You needed to be saved after all and she was the only one who could do it.

Your hopes began to rise as you heard the wooden seat above groan with the shifting of weight. She had heard. Finally, you would be saved. However, you sigh of relief was short lived. A wad of soiled paper crashed into your face, pushing you into the steaming mass beside you.

You struggled free of the tangling mass just in time to catch the light footsteps of the small girl slipping out of the doorway. Heavier footsteps could be heard joining her on her way back to her room. Your salvation was leaving you behind to a cruel fate. The pot would eventually cool, and your body would be left wet and chill with nothing but cold iron to embrace you. Would you drown? Would you climb upon the solid waste to freeze to death instead? Or, spirits forbid, would you burrow into the muck to seek some remnant warmth at the core of the mounds of feces in some desperate, futile attempt to survive long enough to be tossed into a cesspit? The thoughts of your imminent doom caused you to unconsciously swallow, which you immediately regretted.

~~~~~~~~~~

As Toph was hurried along the halls by her maid, she couldn’t help but think about the small person within her armpit. They had been silent and still for far too long and it was starting to worry her. Were they judging her? Were they angry? Had something happened to them? Worry plagued her as she finally reached her room.

“Do you want me to fetch you some water? How about I tuck you into bed?” the maid’s kindness was grating and Toph was nearly at her limit.

“Enough! I’m tired. I’ll tuck myself into bed. Goodnight.” And with that, the blind girl slammed the door in the older woman’s face. Toph made her way over to her bed, crawling beneath the covers while making enough noise to satisfy her attendant. She settled in and waited for the maid to leave, listening intently as she obligingly shuffled off, muttering about poor manners.

When the maid was finally out of earshot, Toph loosened her arm and opened her armpit to the cool night air. What was the matter with her friend? She had to know. However, where she had been expecting a plop from the drop of a small form rolling free of a cramped space, silence greeted her. Tenderly, she brushed her fingers along her cramping pit, but only sweat greeted her.

It wasn’t that her tiny friend was judging her. It wasn’t that they were angry. It was something far worse. They weren’t there. The lonely girl wracked her brain for where her only friend had gotten to and came to one horrifying conclusion.

1121111211112121.content:
It had been some time since you had last seen Toph, and things weren’t looking too bright. The smells and tastes had long sense faded into the background, becoming just one more torment in a menagerie of horrors. The iron pot and its contents had begun to cool already, leaving you wet and shivering. At first, you had been determined to simply sit and wait for Toph to find you, but with life threatening cold and exhaustion settling in, that course of action seemed less and less wise. At present, it was all you could do to keep your head above water. However, the stinking masses in the center of the bowl seemed to maintain their heat.

You could feel the heat from the edge where you stood, beaconing to you. They offered warmth, solid footing, and most importantly time in which Toph could come to rescue you. It might have been cold induced delirium or the exhaustion which drove you to your next course of action, but the alternative would certainly have been death. With those thoughts firmly in mind, you waded forward through the thigh deep urine once more in search of a lifeline to carry you through your peril.

As you reached the half submerged load and tiredly extended your hand outwards, the familiar slimy texture of shit met your hand. The wet surface was bulbous and rounded, just as you remembered from your momentary run in before. The thought of what you were about to do caused your already empty stomach to heave. However, as you touched the greasy surface, heat permeated your hand. With a tired resignation, you clambered onto the top of the filth for warmth.

In the presence of a heat source and a solid surface upon which to rest, your tormented body finally gave out. Consciousness slipped from your grasp and the world faded from your awareness. You aren’t sure how long you slept or what you dreamt about, but it didn’t matter. To you, nothing mattered but the brief respite from reality.
1121111211112121.title: Alone in the Pot (T)

11211112111121211.content:
Shivers wracked you body as you shook uncontrollably. The surface beneath you was a cold lump of filth, now sucking what precious heat remained to you. Your body was numb and your senses were dull. It was the dead of night, so stark darkness greeted you when you finally managed to muster the strength to open your eyes. It was the end. You could feel your body starting its final decline into death. No more options remained to you except to close your eyes and go back to sleep. However, the question remained, why had you woken up.

You couldn’t really say that you cared what had awakened you from your final slumber, but a niggling curiosity at the back of your mind tickled at you incessantly. It tormented you, making you feel itchy all over, pushing you to stir. There was something important you were missing, something which you really ought to notice. With a surge of sensation, sound returned.

“Where are you? Please answer me.”

The sob choked voice shook you with its proximity; the source would be directly above you. Your mind struggled to make sense of what was happening. Were you dreaming? Were you dead? The cogs began to whir as your brain shook of its lethargy. Toph had come to rescue you. She hadn’t left you to die.

Weakly, you forced air from your throat, straining to make a sound. However, nothing came out. The building ammonia fumes had robbed you of your voice. Not even so much as a squeak escaped you. Your salvation had arrived and you were powerless to alert her to your presence. You were about to give into despair when a thought struck you, a desperate thought.

~~~~~~~~~~

Toph waited anxiously above the chamber pot, the scent of her own waste nearly gagging her, and hoping that she wasn’t too late. She crouched over the wooden seat which ringed the rim; her hands placed upon the edges of the cast iron so as to better pick up any vibrations. She had been calling for nearly fifteen minutes now and still there had been no response.

Maybe he hadn’t fallen into the black iron pot? Maybe he was somewhere else entirely. However, the girl knew it was only wishful thinking. She would have felt him land through her feet had he dropped anywhere along the hall and she was sure he wasn’t in her room. This was the only place he could be.

If only she hadn’t been so preoccupied with being embarrassed she might have noticed her tiny friend’s absence. She could have found him before any harm had come to him. The possabilities ran through her head. He might have died immediately upon landing. He could have drowned in her pee. He might have been crushed by her solid waste or buried and suffocated. Toph did her best to silence her sobs, but failed miserably.

“Where are you? Please answer me.”

Loss choked her words. They were the same words she had been muttering into her chamber pot for the past fifteen minutes with no response. If only she could see, she could have brought a candle with her and found her friend immediately. Toph felt helpless, reduced to holding her hands against the side of the pot and hoping for some signal. She couldn’t even fish around blindly, lest she knock him under the surface of the acrid liquid beneath and drown him should he be incapacitated.

A single tear dropped from Toph’s cheek to splash in the urine. A soft ripple passed along its surface, easily visible to Toph through her hands. This was the final resting place of her first and only friend. She had killed him. The thought would stick with her always.

So great was Toph’s grief that she almost missed it. The final struggle of someone too tired to yell. The last grasp at hope for someone without any alternative. A single splash reverberated through the edges of the pot, and it wasn’t a tear this time.

Toph’s hand shot out; slowing near the surface and gingerly fishing for her prize. It didn’t take long before she found them. With the tiny form grasped between her fingers, she lifted them high above what had nearly been their tomb into the palm of her other hand. The stench of waste followed them, but it didn’t matter to the desperate girl. She enfolded the small form within her hands, pulling them close to her body to offer extra warmth. When the pounding of her own heart slowed, Toph could just barely make out another heartbeat. Her friend was alive; unconscious but alive. The tears that fell this time were from relief rather than grief.
