121322121112111112111.content:
It was weird. An hour ago you would have considered the prospect of being trapped in someone’s dirt boot as hell. However, having spent the last few minutes trapped in a moving shoe, being stabbed repeatedly by a sharp toe, sitting still for a change seemed like heaven. The smell wasn’t exactly pleasant, but you were grateful for what you did have.

Your leather prison reeked with the smell of sweat and cheese. You had noticed earlier that the sides of the leather were slick with oil, as it had greatly weakened your grip, but as you rested it dawned upon you that the oily substance beneath your fingers was most likely body soil.

The thought did nothing to comfort you. You had been through a lot, but this boot had obviously been through worse. What would happen if you were unable to find a way to escape?

Your thoughts were interrupted as a rough surface brushed against your body. In the darkness, you couldn’t see what the offending object could be, but considering your location it had to be Korra’s toes. Their calloused tips had absentmindedly stroked your hidden form, now slack and resting upon the bottom in the furthest tip of the boot.

Terror gripped your heart as you realized that you no longer fit in with the rest of the surrounding boot. The slight brush against your prone form might have been all Korra had needed to realize that something was in her boot. With mounting terror, you began to struggle back into your corner, hoping against hope that she hadn’t noticed you.
121322121112111112111.title: Korra Brushes Against You with Her Toes (F)*

1213221211121111121111.content:
You were struggling to push your bag back into the tip of the boot in order to press yourself against it once more when tragedy struck. Groping, calloused digits forced their way over your body, curving their way over your body and pushing down on the leather bottom beyond. Terror and a waxy layer of foot slime choked your senses, calling out for you to thrash, to scream, to panic. However, something inside of you stopped you.

How would Korra react to something in her shoe suddenly starting to wriggle? The answer flashed through your mind. She would be unnerved by the unexpected struggles, immediately thinking of a spider or some other creepy-crawly before she thrashed her foot around, crushing you in the process. No! You had to stay still. It was the only path remaining to you that had any chance of survival.

Korra and Asami’s conversation continued above, however you paid it little heed. The clammy appendages cupping your body held your full attention; they’re curved length pressing down upon you. It would take a mere thought for the avatar to crush you, contracting her toes and squeezing you painfully. You doubt such an act would kill you outright, but it was not unlikely that a few bone may be broken were she so inclined. She wouldn’t even know that the object trapped beneath her toes was fragile enough to damage with such a seemingly light gesture. A feeling of helplessness settled in as you realized that you were powerless to do anything save pray that she treated you gently.

A surge of dread filled you as the muscle coiled around you contracted. However, instead of crushing your puny form they instead lifted, the tips of the toes withdrawing to once more probe at your intruding mass. The calloused pads pushed down, applying a bit of pressure before shifting back and forth, questing clumsily in order to identify your nature. You held still, giving away nothing.

The conversation above continued unabated as Korra shifted from light prodding to pushing, rolling you back and forth within the tip of her boot. In your movement, you noticed that the backpack wasn’t with you. Perhaps it was still lodged deeply within the tip of the boot, safely out of reach of harm. You released a sigh of relief that the fragile equipment would not be damaged before stifling a giggle at the absurdity of the thought. You might not survive the next ten seconds, what did a backpack matter?

Korra might have sensed the slight movement stifling a giggle had caused, because at that moment her toes paused. They’re weight rested upon you, pressing into your chest, abdomen, groin, and legs with a pressure which wasn’t quite painful. However, there was no guarantee that such gentle treatment might continue. Should the avatar suddenly turn violent, there was little you could do to stop her.

What would you do if her gentle probing became something much more dangerous? Under such circumstances, would you have a choice in the matter? The only thing you might do to stop her was wriggle, informing her that it was no mere pebble which she crushed but a living, breathing creature. Under such circumstances, she might take the time to free you from the leather which had come to encompass so much of your life, but then again she might just panic and crush you as you had feared before.

Suddenly, you felt the ball of her foot lift to your side, and with a surge of terror the toes shuffled you beneath the calloused surface.

A surprised shriek was torn from your mouth as you body was pushed roughly beneath the ball of Korra’s foot. The flesh here was still slightly damp from her earlier shower, and the clammy surface was that much more chilled. Your body was tensed as you waited for the impending crunch as you were crushed into the leather beneath. You waited and waited, sweating profusely despite the damp chill. One last, insane thought rushed through your head, wondering if the dampness from the bath had spared you from overheating. You laid there, awaiting for the impending death which hovered above you for what seemed like an eternity before your killer descended once more to claim your life, however it wasn’t your fate to die yet.

Instead of the crushing force you had imagined, the ball of Korra’s foot came down almost gently. The calloused, damp surface coming to rest gently against you abdomen. Slowly, so terribly slowly, the flesh above you started to move, further mapping out your dimensions. Laughter sounded from the outside world, reminding you that Korra neither knew what you were nor cared enough to let you presence interrupt her conversation. It was a bitter reminder of exactly how insignificant you were at your size.

Something tore your attention away from your thoughts; away from the foot above and your own predicament. It wasn’t immediately obvious, even you weren’t aware of what had grasped your attention so strongly with such pressing matters to worry about, but with a growing realization you began to realize something. The boot was starting to tilt.

It wasn’t a sudden tilt, as you might have expected while Korra was walking. It was a gradual tilt, a gentler tilt. Korra didn’t know what she had in her shoe, but it was strange enough that she didn’t want to smash it before taking a look. Perhaps she thought you a lost bathroom implement. Regardless, the pressure above you disappeared completely, allowing you to fall bonelessly towards the safety of the arch below. You hit Korra’s heel, releasing a sigh of relief at the newfound space above. The clatter of loose supplies was the only warning you had before your pack struck you full on in the face. The already pitch black confines of the boot seemed to grow darker still as consciousness left you.
1213221211121111121111.title: Korra Pulls You Under Her Foot (F)*

12132212111211111211111.content:
Darkness and pain greeted you as your mind slowly regained some semblance of cognizance. There was something urgent you needed to address, some niggling itch in the deeper recesses of your mind, but the cloudy haze which hung upon your thoughts obscured such memories, leaving only a dull ache behind your eyes. Where were you? You longed to answer such a question, but opening your eyes seemed an impossible task at the moment. Perhaps it would be best to simply lay for a while and regain your strength?

"And if we bring him to Tenzen, what? They'll ask a few question, lock him up, and we'll be no closer to finding my father." A feminine voice reached you in your stupor, thick with bitterness.

"And you think we can do any better?" A deeper voice answered the first, feminine and challenging.

"It wouldn't hurt to try." The first voice retorted back with an accusatory tone.

"What do you plan to do, flick him until he talks? I nearly killed him by accident. What if you hurt him, huh? He's too small!" The deeper voice sounded exasperated. The voices were starting to seem familiar somehow, but you weren't exactly in the right state of mind to be remembering much.

"You can heal him with your water bending." Water bending. For some reason it filled you with revulsion.

"Not if you accidentally kill him." Somehow, you realized they were talking about you. Mention of injury and death sent a chill through your spine.

"There are other ways to get answers besides pain." The lighter voice grew quiet as it spoke, as if thinking.

"Like what?"

"I'm still thinking about that. However, I know for a fact if we turn him over to Tenzen, we'll never get any answers." There was a long pause.

As if a doorway had opened, your memory began to return. You'd been caught! Those voices, you knew who they belonged to. The Avatar and Mr. Sato's daughter. They'd both been there when the avatar pulled you from her boot. Ignoring the stinging brightness, you opened your eyes, forcing them to adjust to the bright daylight that filtered in through a nearby window.

The room around you was open and spacious, ornately ornately in the style of the airbenders. Wooden beams were exposed in the tan mortar walls, making it seem as if they had been embedded into the structure. A few pieces of wooden furniture was easily recognizable, but on the whole the room seemed sparse. It took only a moment for you to recognize where you were, the end table next to the bed. Luckily for you, the Avatar and the Asami were both preoccupied with their argument, allowing you the chance to make your escape.

"You're right." The avatar deflated as resignation colored her voice. You quickly pulled yourself into a crawl, your limbs screaming n agony.

"I know." Asami's voice took on a soothing tone.

"How are we going to do this?" Korra's usual spunk was back in a flash now that she had a clear goal. By now you had managed to reach the end of the table near the bed. It was a long way own and a long way across, and you doubted you would make it either way. It was then that you remembered that you were missing your pack.

"First, we need to find a proper cell. Else, he may escape." At Asami's words, a sudden realization hit you and without looking you dropped to the ground. Usually eyes tended to be drawn towards the subject of a conversation. Hopefully you had gotten down in time.

"We could always stick him back in my boot." There was a hint of humor in Korra's voice. Though you didn't turn your head to look, the avatar's voice definitely seemed clearer, as if she were facing you. Thankfully she didn't notice your change in position, else they would have already caught you. Frantically, you looked around without moving, seeking some way off of this end table.

"Maybe, though I'd rather have him somewhere more secure. Do you have any boxes?" With a jolt of excitement, you realized an escape route. Though you couldn't jump across to the bed and you couldn't survive a fall without injury, you could certainly grab the bedding on the fall down and slow your descent. It would be risky, but at your smaller size your body seemed stronger, relatively speaking. Though you weren't sure you could make it, you were sure you didn't have a choice.

"Probably." In a sudden burst, you got up, ignoring your body's screams of protest. Without allowing yourself the time to hesitate, you rushed off of the edge, reaching out to grasp the dangling blanket before you. The pit of your stomach jolted as you managed to latch on, but were unable to fully halt your descent. Still, you managed to slow yourself enough that by the time you reached the floor, you were able to catch yourself on all fours with minimal injury.

"Then let's... He's gone!" Asami's voice rose in surprise and you realized your time was short. You needed to find someplace to hide, and quickly.

"That's impossible. He was there just a second ago." You didn't even pay attention to Korra's words as you rushed forward beneath the bed, heading for the other side. You hoped against hope that something would show up, some miraculous means by which to escape. The ground beneath you shook as a rapid series of footsteps hit the ground.

"I've got the door blocked. Check the floor." The avatar's determined voice rang out from the direction of the door, marking that direction as a dead end. If only you had had another minute before they had realized you were gone. A series of soft impact marked Asami's steps as she hurriedly moved towards the bed.
12132212111211111211111.title: Waking Up

121322121112111112111111.content:
Without stopping, you turned your head about, searching desperately for a way out. However, little but bare floor met your gaze. Besides a wardrobe, the bed, and the end table, there was no furniture to speak of. It was the airbender's way to live modesty, and as a result, there was little in the way of cover. Still, the bed had legs, which would offer some form of cover.

Panic fuelled you as you rushed towards the nearest leg, a large wooden pillar. It was more than large enough to conceal you at your current size, though you doubted it would serve for long. In a rush, you dove behind it, pressing your back against its solid frame. The rustle of cloth greeted your ears as Asami lifted the bedding, checking beneath the bed.

"I don't see him." After a moment's pause, the young woman's voice reverberated loudly within the enclosed space.

"Search the legs. He may be hiding behind one of them." You cursed at the avatar's remark. You realized your capture was inevitable, but Korra's added advice wasn't appreciated. The sound of hands on wood could be heard as Asami crawled around, presumably checking around the end table's legs. It wouldn't be long until she moved on to your spot.

"See anything?" A note of anticipation hung in Korra's voice as she questioned her friend.

"Nothing. I'm heading to the other side. Keep your eyes peeled." There was a tremor of frustration in Asami's voice as she rose to her feet.

With a flash of inspiration, you realized this was your chance. With the bed shielding you from the avatar's eyes and Asami walking around, you had a chance to retreat to the other side of the bed, the side that had just been searched. You doubted it would save you from discovery, but it might buy you a minute or two. Once more, you charged beneath the bed, reaching the other side and taking cover. Again, the rustle of cloth met your ears as Asami got down on all fours in search of her missing captive.

"I'm not seeing him!" Exacerbation colored Asami's voice.

"He has to be here somewhere. Check the pillows in case he managed to get on the bed." At Korra's suggestion, Asami withdrew, granting you a few minute's reprieve. You couldn't keep this up forever. Casting your head about, you looked desperately for an out.

"Come on." You desperately whispered to yourself, urging yourself to find an answer. There had to be a gap in the wood, or a hole in the wall somewhere. However, the room was well kept and neither of these things made themselves apparent. Perhaps there was some way to climb up the legs of the bed and into the cross beams of the bed? A quick glance dissuaded that notion as only sleek wood met your eyes.

"He's not here either."

"Toss me one of the blankets from the wardrobe. I'll use it to block the door's gap so i can search with you." Asami's booted feet tapped across the floor at the avatar's suggestion, and you realized that you were out of time. You might avoid one pair of eyes, but two would be impossible. You had to act fast, even if it was something stupid, if you had any hope to get away.

In a mad dash, you rushed towards the wardrobe, Asami's longer stride carrying her there far faster than you could have ever hoped to reach it. However, your goal wasn't the wardrobe. You reached the young woman's shoes as she was gathering up the blanket. Realizing you only had a moment to act, you quickly jumped onto her foot, springing off of it in order to reach the bottom of the wardrobe. Hopefully, Asami would be too preoccupied with the blanket to see you. You held your breath as you clambered onto the wooden panel, hoping her boots were sturdy enough to shield your presence.
121322121112111112111111.title: Cat and Mouse

1213221211121111121111111.content:
Without warning, a hand seized you from above, wrapping around your fragile torso with a crushing grip. The air rushed from your lungs and panic surged through you as you realized you could breathe. The floor fell away from your feet as you were hoisted upwards, towards your captor.

"Got him!" Asami dropped the blanket as she called out, bringing her other hand up to your side. In a moment, the woman relinquished her death grip on you in favor of a more open grasp. You took a shuddering breath.

"Where was he?" In a moment, the Avatar was look over Asami's shoulder, her icy blue eyes boring into you.

"The wardrobe."
